metadata.synopsis: After successfully sabotaging radar-guided Nazi guns, Mallory (Robert Shaw) and Miller (Edward Fox) find themselves attached to an elite American unit known as Force 10. The unlikely duo must accompany Force 10 leader Col. Barnsby (Harrison Ford) and his men as they search for an escaped Nazi spy whom only Mallory and Miller can identify. As the team travels behind enemy lines, Barnsby begins to fall for rugged Russian resistance fighter Maritza (Barbara Bach).

reviews: Although the plot is a bit of a bore, the actors are amusing, chiefly due to where this picture lies in their filmographies.
As a story it does feel rather convenient and derivative, referring to the Alistair MacLean book rather than following it.
Force 10 From Navarone is an above average example of farfetched, easy on the intellect and high on adventure, slightly tongue-in-cheek movie making.

Despite its chilly reception from both critics and audiences - and while it's certainly no classic like its excellent predecessor - Force 10 from Navarone works as an undemanding action film bolstered by an aptly chosen cast.
It's unbelievable that a movie which cost so much money seems to have been made on the cheap.
Force 10 is a mission that should probably have been aborted.
To say it's action-packed is an understatement

It doesn't leave much of an impression; a director like Guy Hamilton, a graduate of four of the Bond pictures, can turn out action movies like this in his sleep. This time, alas, that's apparently what he did.
A very cool, unpretentious war film about a mission to blow up a dam.
Entertaining war flick shadowed by superior original.
A guilty pleasure to be sure, but Ford is great and Robert Shaw's final speech is irresistible.
